data.value: , this function constructs an FIR filter with linear phase and (approximately) the given frequency response.

From the given set of frequencies and gains, the desired response is constructed in the frequency domain. The inverse FFT is applied to the desired response to create the associated convolution kernel, and the first
coefficients of this kernel, scaled by
The FIR filter will have linear phase. The type of filter is determined by the value of 'numtaps` and
flag. There are four possible combinations:
is False, type I filter is produced
is False, type II filter is produced
is True, type III filter is produced
is True, type IV filter is produced
Magnitude response of all but type I filters are subjects to following constraints:
type II  -- zero at the Nyquist frequency
type III -- zero at zero and Nyquist frequencies
type IV  -- zero at zero frequency
The number of taps in the FIR filter.
The frequency sampling points. Typically 0.0 to 1.0 with 1.0 being Nyquist.  The Nyquist frequency is half
must be nondecreasing. A value can be repeated once to implement a discontinuity. The first value in
must be 0, and the last value must be
The filter gains at the frequency sampling points. Certain constraints to gain values, depending on the filter type, are applied, see Notes for details.

The size of the interpolation mesh used to construct the filter. For most efficient behavior, this should be a power of 2 plus 1 (e.g, 129, 257, etc). The default is one more than the smallest power of 2 that is not less than
Window function to use. Default is "hamming". See
for the complete list of possible values. If None, no window function is applied.

children.type_: string or (string, float) or float, or None, optional

data.value: This is the Nyquist frequency. Each frequency in
Whether resulting impulse response is symmetric/antisymmetric. See Notes for more details.
The sampling frequency of the signal. Each frequency in
The filter coefficients of the FIR filter, as a 1-D array of length
FIR filter design using the window method.
A lowpass FIR filter with a response that is 1 on [0.0, 0.5], and that decreases linearly on [0.5, 1.0] from 1 to 0:

signature.value: firwin2(numtaps, freq, gain, nfreqs=None, window='hamming', nyq=None, antisymmetric=False, fs=None)
